title: About
text:
This research study was conducted for SMT201: Geographic Information Systems for Urban Planning in AY2022-2023 Term 1, in Singapore Management University
Instructor: Kim Tin Seong

title: Catch Them All
text:
Introduction



This website provides an overview of our assessment of the accessibility and catchment areas of the Stage 4 Thomson-East Coast line MRT stations. A more comprehensive analysis can be found in our report.

title: Catch Them All
text:
Motivation
With Singapore Green Plan 2030, we want to explore how the expansion of TEL Stage 4 MRT Stations can help in making public transportation and Singapore more sustainable and greener.

title: Catch Them All
text:
Background
Thomson East Coast line (TEL) was announced by the Land Transport Authority on 15 August 2014. It hopes to better serve communities living in the North-South corridor and the East by cutting down travel times to the Central area from 55min to 35min.
This is in conjunction with Singaporeâ€™s Green Plan which, among others, aims to significantly reduce our carbon emissions and ensure that Singapore is more sustainable. One way would be to reduce demand for private transportation.
Our focus is on the Stage 4 stations(Founders Memorial to Bayshore) , which are currently in the works and will be opened by 2025.

title: Catch Them All
text:
Deliverables

Deliverable #1
We will provide both the buffer regions and the ISO-areas (using QNEAT3) of the aforementioned stations. The maximum walking distance for both buffer and ISO-area is 1000m while maximum cycling distance is 1500m.


Deliverable #2
Afterwards, we will be conducting an analysis of the various amenities and buildings that lie within the catchment area.


Deliverable #3
We will also find the population size of the people served by this line by using the composite subzone areas and population.

title: Group 11: Catch them All
text:
Deliverables and Goals

Goal #1: Find buffer and ISO-area
We will provide both the buffer regions and the ISO-areas (using QNEAT3) of the aforementioned stations for both walking and cycling. The maximum walking distance for both buffer and ISO-area is 1000m while maximum cycling distance is 1500m.


Goal #2: Find the amenities within those areas
Afterwards, we will be conducting an analysis of the various amenities and buildings that lie within the catchment area. The data will be from the OSM layer and confirmed using Google Maps. This will be used to understand the accessibility and usefulness of the line in connecting residents.


Goal #3: Find Population Size within Area
We will also find the population size of the people served by this line by using the composite subzone areas and population. (uh, Xin Hui, can explain this?)

title: Catch Them All
text:
Problem and Aim
Presently, however, private transportation is preferred due to its ease and comfort. As a result, this study aims to see how accessible and convenient TEL Stage 4 MRT stations are for first and last mile journeys. We will do so by analysing two ways in which Singaporeans may get to the MRT - walking or cycling. This will prove whether the construction of TEL Stage 4 MRT is competent to successfully encourage people to use public transportation.

title: Introduction
text:
Our project aims to

Understand how well the new MRT stations will serve the people coming to and from this area
Access its accessibility to various amenities such as restaurants, schools and shopping malls
Find out which areas could have more roads and lines built to maximise the accessibility of the MRT stations
Find the population size of the people being served.

title: Introduction
text:
Motivations
According to the Singapore Green Plan, the government wishes to substantially reduce our carbon emissions in order to combat climate change. One such way it aims to achieve this is by encouraging public transport instead of private transport.
At present, most Singapore residents use public transport such as buses and trains. This is due to the costliness in purchasing and maintaining a car. However, many people still find public transportation to be insufficient, with many wealthier people and families opting for car ownership instead. This is partially driven by the comfort and ease that driving provides to its riders.
However, this contributes to our carbon emissions and makes meeting the goals set by the Green Plan difficult to achieve. This is compounded by the fact that car ownership is a negative externality. Despite the convenience it affords to its owners, it aggravates traffic and is a source of various types of pollution apart from air pollution, such as noise.
This points to a need to strengthen our public transportation system and to accommodate the diverse needs of Singapore residents.
